First, the code structure:

#include <stdio.h>
#include <string.h>
#include <stdbool.h>

// Function to check leap year
int is_leap(int year) {
    return (year % 400 == 0) || (year %4 ==0 && year %100 !=0);
}

int main() {
    // First part: read 5 lines and compute first_result
    struct menu_item {
        int num;
        int exp;
    };
    struct menu_item menu[5];

    for (int i=0; i<5; i++) {
        char m_str[100];
        fgets(m_str, sizeof(m_str), stdin);
        m_str[strcspn(m_str, "\n")] = 0; // remove newline
        int len = strlen(m_str);
        int exp_char = m_str[len-1] - '0';
        int exp = exp_char;
        if (exp ==0) exp =10;
        menu[i].num = atoi(m_str);
        menu[i].exp = exp;
    }

    // Sort the menu by exp
    int compare(const void *a, const void *b) {
        struct menu_item *item_a = (struct menu_item*)a;
        struct menu_item *item_b = (struct menu_item*)b;
        return (item_a->exp - item_b->exp);
    }
    qsort(menu, 5, sizeof(struct menu_item), compare);

    // Compute first_result
    int ans =0;
    for (int i=1; i<5; i++) {
        int m_num = menu[i].num;
        int divided = m_num /10;
        if (m_num %10 !=0) divided++;
        ans += divided *10;
    }
    int first_result = ans + menu[0].num;

    // Second part: compute second_result
    int current_n = first_result;
    int current_day =4; // 'f' is 4
    bool initial_leap = is_leap(current_n);
    const char *ans_str = initial_leap ? "ly" : "nly";

    while (1) {
        bool leap = is_leap(current_n);
        int next_day;
        if (leap) {
            next_day = (current_day +2) %7;
        } else {
            next_day = (current_day +1) %7;
        }
        current_day = next_day;
        current_n +=1;

        if (current_day ==4) { // 'f'
            bool current_leap = is_leap(current_n);
            if ( ( (ans_str == "ly" && current_leap) ) || ( (ans_str == "nly" && !current_leap) ) ) {
                break;
            }
        }
    }
    int second_result = current_n;

    // Third part: compute final answer
    long long total =0;
    int N = second_result;
    for (int i=1; i<=N; i++) {
        int k = N /i;
        total += (long long)i * k * (k+1)/2;
    }
    printf("%lld\n", total);

    return 0;
}

    if ( (initial_is_ly && current_leap) || (!initial_is_ly && !current_leap) ) {
        break;
    }
}

Now, testing for possible errors.

Another point: in the first part, when reading the input lines, the code uses atoi(m_str). But if the input line has leading or trailing characters that are not digits, atoi will stop at the first non-digit. But according to the problem's first Python code, the input lines are such that m is converted to an integer, so the input lines must be numeric strings. So assuming that the input is correct, this is okay.

Also, the exponent is taken from the last character. So if the input line is "123a", then the last character is 'a', which would be converted to 97 - '0' = 97, which is invalid. But according to the problem's first Python code, the input is such that the last character is a digit. So the code can proceed under that assumption.

Another possible issue: in the first part's sorting, the comparator function is defined inside main. In C, the comparator function for qsort must be declared before the qsort call, or placed outside. Wait, in the code above, the compare function is defined inside main, which is not allowed in C. Because functions cannot be nested in C. So that's an error.

Ah, right! The compare function must be outside main or declared before.

So need to move the compare function outside.

So, reorganizing the code:

#include <stdio.h>
#include <string.h>
#include <stdbool.h>

// Function to check leap year
int is_leap(int year) {
    return (year % 400 == 0) || (year %4 ==0 && year %100 !=0);
}

// Comparator function for qsort
int compare(const void *a, const void *b) {
    struct menu_item *item_a = (struct menu_item*)a;
    struct menu_item *item_b = (struct menu_item*)b;
    return (item_a->exp - item_b->exp);
}

int main() {
    // First part: read 5 lines and compute first_result
    struct menu_item {
        int num;
        int exp;
    };
    struct menu_item menu[5];

    for (int i=0; i<5; i++) {
        char m_str[100];
        fgets(m_str, sizeof(m_str), stdin);
        m_str[strcspn(m_str, "\n")] = 0; // remove newline
        int len = strlen(m_str);
        int exp_char = m_str[len-1] - '0';
        int exp = exp_char;
        if (exp ==0) exp =10;
        menu[i].num = atoi(m_str);
        menu[i].exp = exp;
    }

    // Sort the menu by exp
    qsort(menu, 5, sizeof(struct menu_item), compare);

    // Compute first_result
    int ans =0;
    for (int i=1; i<5; i++) {
        int m_num = menu[i].num;
        int divided = m_num /10;
        if (m_num %10 !=0) divided++;
        ans += divided *10;
    }
    int first_result = ans + menu[0].num;

    // Second part: compute second_result
    int current_n = first_result;
    int current_day =4; // 'f' is 4
    bool initial_is_ly = is_leap(current_n);

    while (1) {
        bool leap = is_leap(current_n);
        int next_day;
        if (leap) {
            next_day = (current_day +2) %7;
        } else {
            next_day = (current_day +1) %7;
        }
        current_day = next_day;
        current_n +=1;

        if (current_day ==4) { // 'f'
            bool current_leap = is_leap(current_n);
            if ( (initial_is_ly && current_leap) || (!initial_is_ly && !current_leap) ) {
                break;
            }
        }
    }
    int second_result = current_n;

    // Third part: compute final answer
    long long total =0;
    int N = second_result;
    for (int i=1; i<=N; i++) {
        int k = N /i;
        total += (long long)i * k * (k+1)/2;
    }
    printf("%lld\n", total);

    return 0;
}

Now, the compare function is outside main, so that's okay.

Another possible issue: in the first part, the menu array is declared inside main, which is okay in C99 and later. But if the compiler is set to C89, it might require variables to be declared at the top. But assuming that's not an issue here.

Testing the code for possible errors.

Another point: in the first part, when the exponent is 0, it's set to 10. The code does that correctly.

Now, the third part's loop: for N up to the second_result, which could be large. For example, if second_result is 1e6, the loop runs 1e6 times, which is manageable. But if it's 1e9, it's a problem. However, the problem's test cases probably don't have such large N, or the second program's loop terminates quickly.

Overall, this should work.
